author: Moses
description: Genesis is a book of beginnings that introduces central themes of the Bible, such as creation and redemption.

author: Moses
description: God reveals himself to his people and delivers them from slavery in Egypt to establish a covenant with them in the desert.

author: Moses
description: The Israelites receive instructions from God at the base of Mount Sinai concerning how to live as God's holy people.

author: Moses
description: Because the Israelites are unwilling to enter the land of Canaan, their entire generation is forced to wander in the Desert of Sinai for 38 years.

author: Moses
description: In a series of farewell messages, Moses exhorts the new generation of Israelites to live as his obedient people in the promised land.

author: Possibly Joshua
description: God enables Joshua to lead the armies of Israel to victory over the Canaanites in the promised land.

author: Possibly Samuel
description: In danger of losing the promised land, the Israelites are delivered again and again by God through leaders known as 'judges.'

author: Possibly Samuel
description: Ruth, a Moabite woman, proves to be a model of faithfulness in Israel during the period of the judges.

author: Unknown
description: The nation of Israel transitions from being led by God through 'judges' to being led by him through kings.

author: Unknown
description: Second Samuel presents the story of David's 40-year reign, beginning with his rise to become Israel's model king and ending with his subsequent decline caused by sin.

author: Possibly Jeremiah
description: After Solomon's death, the nation is divided into the northern kingdom (Israel) and the southern kingdom (Judah).

author: Possibly Jeremiah
description: Learn from the lessons of the Israelites' history about the consequences of unfaithfulness to God and about God's patience and faithfulness.

author: Possibly Ezra
description: The law and the prophets, like the temple, are more crucial to Israel's continuing relationship with the Lord than the presence or absence of a king; the reigns of the Davidic kings themselves being testimony.

author: Possibly Ezra
description: The law and the prophets, like the temple, are more crucial to Israel's continuing relationship with the Lord than the presence or absence of a king; the reigns of the Davidic kings themselves being testimony.

author: Possibly Ezra
description: A remnant of the Israelites, who had been exiled to Babylonia, return to Judah and Jerusalem to rebuild the temple under God's direction.

author: Possibly Ezra
description: Nehemiah travels from Susa in Elam to Jerusalem in Judah to lead the Jews in rebuilding the city walls.

author: Unknown
description: The book of Esther describes how the Jews of Persia are saved from certain destruction through divine providence.

author: Unknown
description: This wisdom book ponders the question of whether God is a God of justice in the light of life's perplexities, such as human suffering.

author: David, Asaph and Others
description: The book of Psalms contains ancient Israel's favorite hymns and prayers, which were used in their worship of God, the Great King.

author: Solomon and other wise men
description: Proverbs describes the importance of living wisely and in the fear of the Lord as opposed to following the seductive path of folly.

author: Possibly Solomon
description: This wisdom teacher reveals what he has discovered about the meaninglessness of every human endeavor without God at the center of one's life.

author: Possibly Solomon
description: This wisdom writer celebrates the sexual union between a man and a woman as a joyful part of marital life in God's good creation.

author: Isaiah
description: Isaiah predicts imminent judgment — but eventual restoration — for the people of Judah and Jerusalem.

author: Jeremiah
description: Jeremiah, the prophet of the new covenant, predicts Judah's Babylonian exile and ultimate restoration under the Davidic Messiah.

author: Probably Jeremiah
description: The prophet and his fellow Jews lament the devastation of their beloved city at the hands of the Babylonians. In the middle of the book, the theology of Lamentations reaches its apex as it focuses on the goodness of God.

author: Ezekiel
description: Ezekiel the priest assures his fellow Jews that God will one day return them to Jerusalem and restore the temple.

author: Daniel
description: The Most High God is sovereign over all human kingdoms.

author: Hosea
description: Hosea proclaims God's compassion and covenant love that cannot let Israel go.

author: Joel
description: Restoration and blessing will come to the people of Judah only after judgment and repentance.

author: Amos
description: The prophet Amos calls for social justice as the indispensable expression of true piety.

author: Obadiah
description: Obadiah prophesies judgment against the proud Edomites, who are gloating over Jerusalem's devastation by foreign powers.

author: Unknown
description: In this story of God's loving concern for all people, the stubbornly reluctant Jonah represents Israel's jealousy of its favored relationship with God and its unwillingness to share the Lord's compassion with the nations.

author: Micah
description: Micah's message alternates between prophecies of doom and prophecies of hope; the theme is divine judgment and deliverance.

author: Nahum
description: Nahum predicts the Lord's judgment on Nineveh for her oppression, cruelty, idolatry and wickedness.

author: Habakkuk
description: The prophet Habakkuk argues with God over God's ways, which appear to him unfathomable, if not unjust; after receiving replies from God, Habakkuk responds with a beautiful confession of faith.

author: Zephaniah
description: The prophet Zephaniah predicts the coming of the day of the Lord, when God will severely punish the nations, including apostate Judah, but will yet be merciful to his people.

author: Haggai
description: The prophet Haggai calls the complacent people of Judah to resume the rebuilding of the temple and in that way give glory to God.

author: Zechariah
description: The prophet Zechariah rebukes and encourages the discouraged exiles who have returned to Jerusalem from Babylonia to complete the rebuilding of the temple.

author: Malachi
description: The prophet Malachi assures the postexilic Jewish community that the Messianic King will come not only to judge his people but also to bless and restore them.

author: Matthew
description: Matthew presents Jesus as the Jewish Messiah sent by God to fulfill OT prophecy.

author: Mark
description: To encourage his readers to persevere through suffering and persecution, Mark presents Jesus as the Servant-Messiah and Son of God who died as a ransom for sinners.

author: Luke
description: Luke presents Jesus as the Messiah and Lord whose life, death and resurrection make salvation available to all people everywhere.

author: Luke
description: John presents Jesus as the Word, the Messiah and the incarnate Son of God, who has come to reveal the Father and bring eternal life to all who believe in him.

author: Luke
description: Luke shows how the gospel spread rapidly from Jerusalem to the whole Roman Empire, and from its Jewish roots to the Gentile world.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to the church in Rome to present his basic statement of the gospel: God's plan of salvation for all peoples, Jew and Gentile alike.

author: Paul
description: Paul addresses problems in the church and answers questions from the church.

author: Paul
description: Paul encourages the Corinthian believers to be reconciled with him and to reject false apostles who are challenging his authority and creating dissension in the church.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to counter the claims of legalistic Judaizers who were telling the Galatian believers that they must be circumcised and keep the law of Moses in order to be saved.

author: Paul
description: Paul summarizes his gospel of salvation by grace through faith alone and describes the nature and role of the church in God's eternal plan.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to encourage the Christians at Philippi to live joyfully in every circumstance.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to demonstrate that Christ is supreme over every human philosophy and accomplishment.

author: Paul
description: Paul praises the Thessalonian believers for their spiritual maturity and perseverance, and he encourages them to further growth in view of Christ's imminent return.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to correct a misunderstanding concerning the Lord's return and to exhort the Thessalonian believers to be steadfast and to work for a living.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to instruct Timothy concerning the care of the church at Ephesus.

author: Paul
description: Facing imminent death, Paul encourages Timothy to carry on the ministry and faithfully guard the gospel.

author: Paul
description: Paul writes to instruct Titus concerning the care of the church on the island of Crete.

author: Paul
description: Paul urges Philemon to show grace to Onesimus, his runaway slave.

author: Paul
description: The author demonstrates the absolute supremacy and sufficiency of Jesus Christ as revealer and mediator of God's grace.

author: James
description: James emphasizes vital Christianity characterized by good deeds and faith that works.

author: Peter
description: Peter gives instructions on holy living for those suffering persecution.

author: Peter
description: Peter teaches how to deal with false teachers and evildoers who have come into the church.

author: John
description: John writes to assure believers of the certainty of their faith and to refute heretical doctrines teaching that Jesus was not fully human and fully divine.

author: John
description: John writes to urge discernment in supporting traveling teachers, since false teachers were also traveling and teaching heresy.

author: John
description: John writes this letter to commend Gaius for supporting traveling teachers and to rebuke Diotrephes for refusing to welcome them.

author: Jude
description: Jude writes to warn Christians about false teachers who are trying to convince them that being saved by grace gives them license to sin.

author: John
description: John writes to encourage the faithful to stand firm against persecution and compromise in the light of the imminent return of Christ to deliver the righteous and judge the wicked.
